entry.title: SAP Joule for Developers Expands to Private Cloud: Accelerating ABAP Innovation and Transformation
entry.content:
Key Highlights

  • Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now available in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition 2025.
  • New Custom Code Migration capabilities accelerate the transformation of classic ERP code to S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, including:
    • Documentation Chat - Get accurate answers on SAP S/4HANA simplifications.
    • ABAP Program Explain - Understand the business purpose and logic of legacy code.
    • Explain for SAP S/4HANA Test Cockpit Issues - Diagnose and resolve S/4HANA-related Test Cockpit issues using context from simplification items and cookbooks.

Earlier this year, SAP introduced Joule for Developers — a set of embedded artificial intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, including ABAP, that helps developers accelerate application and extension development, reduce costs, and boost productivity.

Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now available for S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition, version 2025, providing comprehensive support for ABAP Cloud use cases. The release also introduces the first Custom Code Migration capabilities, bringing a powerful suite of AI-assisted capabilities purpose-built for ABAP development and cloud delivery.

Best of all, Joule for Developers remains free of charge, enabling customers and partners to integrate it into daily operations and accelerate innovation without commercial barriers.

 

What’s Included

This release for Private Cloud delivers AI-powered support for the core development scenarios ABAP developers rely on every day. Key capabilities include:

  • inline code completion,
  • ABAP/CDS code explanation,
  • automated unit test generation for ABAP and ABAP core data services (CDS),
  • RAP business objects generation,
  • RAP predictive business logic, and
  • OData consumption.

All capabilities are designed to accelerate development, improve code quality, and boost productivity from day one. Additionally, this release introduces the first wave of Custom Code Migration capabilities, designed to accelerate the move from classic SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Cloud Edition. These AI-powered features simplify code analysis and adaptation by:

  • Providing Documentation Chat for quick answers on SAP S/4HANA simplifications:

 

  • Using ABAP Program Explain to clarify the business purpose and implementation logic of legacy code:

 

  • Explaining ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) findings with step-by-step guidance on how to fix the issues, based on simplification items and technical documentation:

 

All capabilities are designed to reduce manual effort, speed up migration projects, and help your teams to modernize their ABAP landscapes with great confidence.

The ABAP AI software development kit, powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management, is now available and offers centralized access to the generative AI hub in SAP AI Core. It leverages the same robust platform SAP uses internally, delivering proven, production-grade infrastructure to customer landscapes. With simplified configuration and governance, development teams can adopt AI capabilities quickly, providing a significant boost to integration efforts.

 

Why This Matters

Private cloud customers require strict governance, security, and operational control - yet they also seek the speed and innovation modern AI-driven development delivers. This release addresses both priorities by enabling:

  • faster development cycles with AI-assisted coding and test generation,
  • stronger knowledge transfer through automated code explanations and copilot interactions,
  • higher delivery quality with automated testing and code migration support, and
  • secure innovation within controlled environments.

 

Looking Ahead

We’re building on this momentum with a series of targeted deliveries aligned to upcoming releases across the BTP ABAP Environment and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Planned updates for BTP ABAP Environment 2511, 2602, and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 include:

  • documentation generation capabilities,
  • enhanced explanations for reports in the Custom Code Migration application,
  • AI-enabled insights on Clean Core–related ATC findings directly within the Custom Code Migration application,
  • code migration and adaptation proposals to support developers working on RISE code adaptation,
  • ABAP CDS annotation and metadata extension generation, and
  • ABAP CDS analytical model generation.

These enhancements will extend Joule’s impact beyond code completion and test generation, supporting documentation, migration and Clean Core compliance, analytical use cases, and addressing more stages of the end-to-end development lifecycle.

 

Free Offer Extended

SAP Joule for Developers will remain free of charge. The extended promotion ensures that all customers and partners can continue to use Joule for Developers capabilities for free.

Access can be requested using the material numbers 8019124 (customers) and 8019541 (TDD partners). This offer now extends beyond the BTP ABAP environment and SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition to include SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition customers running the latest 2025 release.

 

Closing Remarks

SAP Joule for Developers’ delivery for Private Cloud is a significant milestone — combining end-to-end ABAP Cloud with AI use cases, innovative code migration scenarios, and a standardized ABAP AI SDK to bring practical AI assistance directly into everyday development workflows.

With extended free of charge access, we invite every customer and partner to explore SAP Joule for Developers, push its boundaries, and help shape the future of AI-assisted ABAP development.

Start using SAP Joule for Developers today and join us in building the next generation of intelligent, AI-driven ABAP innovation.

For a deeper dive, read the blog post by Simona Marincei, head of ABAP AI.

Learn more about SAP Joule for Developers capabilities here.

entry.title: SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025
entry.content:
Hi folks,

SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now also available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025.
The ABAP AI license materials for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 are the same as for SAP BTP ABAP Environment & SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For more information, please check out the following SAP Note 3571857.

Below, you can find a step-by-step guide on how to activate SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 system.

Have fun and stay tuned for TechEd soon!

Best,
Sebastian

 

Prerequisites

You have a customer account on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and a development system on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and you have prepared the following:

  • Subscription to SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Subscription to SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities
  • Established trust to your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant in your BTP Subaccount, see this link
  • Your user needs Administrator access to your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant
  • Your system needs to be configured so that it trusts server certificates according to the "required" section of the BTP Trust Store.
  • Your system needs to use a client certificate issued by a CA listed in the "required" section of the BTP Trust Store. One way to obtain a client certificate can be found on Manage Destination Certificates (under "Generate a Certificate").
  • You've successfully applied SAP Note 3627794 .
  • Your ABAP system needs to support TLS 1.3. If TLS 1.3 is not enabled, refer to SAP Note 3318423  to activate it.

 

Configuration steps in your SAP BTP subaccount

  1. In your BTP subaccount, navigate to Entitlements. You’ll see a table with all entitlements it already has.
  2. Select Configure Entitlements > Add Service Plans. A popover appears with all entitlements available for your directory/subaccount.
  3. Select the service SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities and then the plan “default”
  4. Select the amount of quota
  5. Select Add Service Plans.
  6. Select Save.

 

  1. Navigate to your subaccount in the SAP BTP cockpit
  2. Go to Services > Service Marketplace.
  3. Choose the SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities tile.
  4. Choose Create and select Plan default




  5. Once the service is created, go to your IAS and navigate to Users & Authorizations > Groups
  6. Check that the group j4d-admin was successfully created
  7. Add your admin user to the created j4a-admin group

     

  8. Navigate to your subaccount in the SAP BTP cockpit
  9. In the navigation go to Services >Instances & Subscriptions
  10. Choose the SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities tile.
  11. Click on Go to Application




  12. Maintain Certificate Mappings app should be opened



    Configuration steps in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 system

    1. Go to your ABAP system, open the transaction APPLDESTCC
    2. Select scenario HTTP - Application Destination and click on Execute


    3. Next, select AIC_ADT_HTTP_PROXY and open the context menu. Choose Create New Application Destination. Now, you're asked to enter the details of your application destination.


       



    4. Enter an Application Destination Name of your choice and select the check mark. 



    5. Now, first enter a Description and select the checkboxes Active and Default.

    6. Fill in the information in the Technical Settings tab:
      1. Target System Settings: In the Host field, enter https://proxy.<your region>.hub.j4a.services.sap. As Protocol, select HTTPS.
      2. (Optional) HTTP Proxy Options: This information is not mandatory.

        Note The region you enter in https://proxy.<your region>.hub.j4a.services.sap must be the same region (not technical key) that you chose for your subaccount, for example "eu10". See Regions and API Endpoints for the ABAP Environment


         

    7. Choose the Logon tab
      1. General Settings: Select Connection to External Server.
      2. Logon Procedure: Select Client Certificate and choose the certificate you wish to use from the dropdown menu
      3. Select Save. You've successfully maintained the connection.



    8. Now, continue in your subaccount in the SAP BTP Cockpit
      1. Select the SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities subscription you have just created (see Subscribing to SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities), or open its details and select Go to Application. You are forwarded to the Maintain Certificate Mappings page.
      2. In the Certificate Mappings section, select Create to receive a one-time password (OTP).
      3. Copy the OTP.

        Note: the OTP is valid for five minutes. If you need a new one, close the pop-up and click on Create again.


    9.  Go to your corresponding ABAP system and run report AIC_ADT_PROXY_CERTIFICATE. Select Execute.
      1. Paste the one-time password that you've copied in the previous step
      2. (Optional) If you wish to use a new certificate that you haven't used in step 1, select Use Custom SSL Client PSE ID. Click in the Client PSE ID field and choose the new certificate from the value help. Now, you can go back to step 1 and switch to the new certificate.
      3. Select Execute



      4. You've successfully registered your certificate!


         

    10. You can now create a new ABAP Project in ADT (using its latest version) and check out SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities

entry.title: Overhead Accounting with Universal Parallel Accounting in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Continuing the blog series on Universal Parallel Accounting and specifically the topic of Overhead Accounting, I’ll now explain the changes introduced with SAP S/4HANA 2025.

If you read my original blog, you will recall that with Universal Parallel Accounting we extend the ledger approach to all financial applications, to ensure that the ledger settings are used consistently in Asset Accounting, Controlling and Actual Costing in addition to General Ledger Accounting. All value flows then take place with reference to this ledger, so allocations are ledger-specific to reflect the different inputs coming from Asset Accounting, General Ledger Accounting, and so on. If you build an activity-based model to charge costs to production or services, then the cost rates can also be ledger-specific, but the quantities themselves are captured only once.

Overhead Accounting with Universal Parallel Accounting 

With the initial delivery of Universal Parallel Accounting, SAP S/4HANA did not support indirect activity allocation (transactions KSC1-5) or template allocation (transactions CPT1-3, CPTA and CPTD) and if you tried to run these transactions, the system issued a message saying that the function was not supported because the business function for Universal Parallel Accounting was active. This changes with SAP S/4HANA 2025, where SAP supports indirect activity allocation and template allocation for environments 001 (Cost Estimate/Production Orders) and 009 (Process Orders).

Activity-Based Allocations

The simplest activity allocation is the direct activity allocation that is typically used to allocate costs between cost centers or from cost centers to orders and projects. Direct activity allocations were supported with the initial delivery of Universal Parallel Accounting to ensure the correct reporting of production and service costs. The amount of work performed is captured either using time recording, confirmations on the shop floor, or manually using transaction KB21N. Before you can record a direct activity allocation, you must define a cost rate for each unit of work and with the advent of Universal Parallel Accounting, this rate can be ledger-specific.

Indirect activity allocations, by contrast, are used when it is not possible to use confirmations or time recording to determine the amount of work performed, but instead you wish to allocate the total activity hours worked by a call center to the markets served or the total number of kilowatt hours supplied to your production cost centers.  There is no change to the way you set up an indirect activity allocation to calculate the quantities to be used as a basis for the allocation.  You can either manually enter the number of hours worked by the call center or have the system calculate the number of kilowatt hours supplied by looking at the machine hours on the receiving cost centers. The difference is that there can potentially be as many cost rates for these activities as you have set up ledgers.  While the amount-based allocations became part of universal allocation in SAP S/4HANA 2025, indirect activity allocation continues to use the legacy transactions KSC1-5 to manage and run the allocation cycles.

Template allocation is used instead of routings and recipes to calculate the amount of production activity expected. A template allocation might be as simple as determining that a setup or quality check is needed once for every production order or use its own function to calculate activity usage, so you might determine that shopfloor movements are dependent on the number of components in the bill of material (BOM) or the number of work center changes in the routing. Again, template allocation in SAP S/4HANA 2025 reuses the legacy transactions CPT1-3 to define the templates, and CPTA and CPTD to run the template allocation for production and process orders. This means that you can reuse any functions you may have created to determine whether an activity should be charged or to calculate the quantity of activity used.  As we saw for indirect activity allocation, you can potentially apply different cost rates for this quantity depending on the ledger.

With Universal Parallel Accounting the COST table becomes obsolete and is replaced by the ACCOSTRATE table with its link to the ledger. This means that you cannot use the legacy transaction KP26 to define the cost rates, but must use the Manage Cost Rates - Plan app or load the cost rates from SAP Analytics Cloud for Planning. Since the ACCOSTRATE table does not yet contain a field for the business process,  the sender object for an indirect activity allocation or a template allocation can only be the cost center/activity type combination and business processes (transactions CP01-03) are not yet supported.

Indirect Activity Allocation

At first glance, an indirect activity allocation looks like a distribution or assessment cycle, but the sender is not a cost center, but rather the combination of cost center and activity type and the sender rules are based on quantities (hence the link to the activity type) rather than amounts (where the cost center alone would be sufficient). In Universal Parallel Accounting, amount-based allocations are now executed using universal allocation, but quantity-based allocations continue to use the legacy transactions to determine the quantities used.

Figure 1 shows the segment header of an indirect activity allocation cycle to allocate kilowatt hours from an energy cost center to a group of production cost centers. You can access this screen using transaction KSC1. Notice that the segment uses the sender rule Quantities Calculated Inversely because we are going to use the total machine time recorded on the production cost centers to determine the number of kilowatt hours to be charged to each cost center. The receiver tracing factor is then Actual Activity, which in our case is the amount of machine time worked by the production cost centers. 

Figure 1: Segment Header of Indirect Activity Allocation Cycle

Indirect activity allocations build their charge model using different activity types from those used for direct activity allocations. Figure 2 shows the activity type for the allocation of kilowatt hours from the energy cost center. To perform the inverse calculation specified in the sender rule shown in Figure 1, you will need an activity type with Activity Type Category 2 (Indirect calculation, indirect allocation). Alternatively, if you don’t want to derive the quantity used from the receiver quantities but rather to spread an activity quantity that you have entered manually for your sender cost center, you’ll need to create an activity type with Activity Type Category 3 (Manual Entry, Indirect Allocation) and switch the sender rule to Posted Quantities. You can then use transaction KB51N to capture the total quantity for the cost center/activity type combination to be allocated for the period.

Figure 2: Activity Type Master Record showing ATyp category 2 (Indirect determination, indirect allocation

Once you have defined the master data, you can enter the energy cost center in combination with the activity type for the kilowatt hours as the Sender and the production cost centers as the Receiver in the Senders/Receivers tab of the Indirect Activity Allocation Cycle as shown in Figure 3, thus establishing the relationship needed to run the allocation.

Figure 3: Senders and Receivers within Indirect Activity Allocation Cycle

Before you can run the allocation, you’ll need to maintain an activity rate for the cost center/activity type combination using the Manage Cost Rates – Plan app to calculate the initial rate as shown in Figure 4. You can choose whether you create different cost rates per ledger if the differences between the rates are significant or you can work with ledger-independent cost rates to simplify the planning process. Note that the ledger is not a default field, so to maintain ledger-specific cost rates in the Manage Cost Rates - Plan app, you will have to add the field to the layout using the View Settings button.

Figure 4: Ledger-Specific Cost Rates for Kilowatt Hours

Figure 5 shows the result of running the indirect activity allocation for the sender (the energy cost center).  The machine hours on the production cost centers have been used to derive the total kilowatt hours of energy used in the period and this is shown in the Actual Activity column.

Figure 5: Result of Indirect Activity Allocation, Showing Activity Quantity Assigned to Sender Cost Center and Activity Type

These quantities are valuated with the cost rates defined in Figure 4 and the Energy Cost Center debited and the Production Cost Centers credited under the G/L account associated with the activity type. You can identify such postings by searching for the Business Transaction Type RKIL in the Display Line Items app.  Figure 6 shows the postings from the energy cost center in ledger 0L. You can view the other documents by changing the ledger selection.

Figure 6: Ledger-Specific Line Items for Indirect Activity Allocation

Template Allocation

Template allocation is a more sophisticated way of including overhead costs in your product costs and assigning them to your production orders and process orders at period close. As I described in my previous blog, SAP has been moving various tasks out of the period close and making them event-based, but template allocation will continue to run at period close to allow customers to continue to use their existing functions to calculate the quantities used.

The Differences between Traditional and Event-based WIP and Variance Calculation  

Overhead calculation and template allocation are related and the system uses the costing sheet and overhead keys for overhead calculation to determine the template to be applied. Template allocation is particularly useful if you need to make sure that the outstanding balance on your cost centers is zero at the end of the period and all costs have been charged to production (a legal requirement in some parts of the world), when the use of percentage overhead rates almost always leaves a balance on the cost center at period close.

Templates are defined using transactions CPT1-3 and comprise a list of sender cost centers/activity types together with planned and actual quantities. The functions that can be called are grouped as environments, and the initial delivery will only support environments 001 (Cost Estimate/Production Orders) and 009 (Process Orders), with environments for WBS elements, networks and service orders planned for later.

You can either enter activity quantities to the template manually, such as one quality check per order, or have the system calculate them using formulas that read related driver quantities. SAP delivers a library of standard functions for each environment, and these can be extended as required. Additionally, you can set conditions that determine whether the activity is to be charged at all, so you might only charge a configuration activity if the material to be manufactured is configurable. This part of template allocation does not change with the move to Universal Parallel Accounting.

Template allocation is just a more dynamic form of direct activity allocation, so the activity types included in the template must have Activity Type Category 1 (Manual Entry, Manual Allocation), as shown for a Quality Check in Figure 7. This is the same setting as for the activity types you might use for order confirmation (setup, machine time, labor, and so on) or time recording (consulting hours, and so on).Figure 7: Activity Type Master Record showing ATyp category 1

As we saw for indirect activity allocation, you’ll need to use the Manage Cost Rates - Plan app to enter a cost rate for the quality checks to be calculated by the template, as shown in Figure 8.

Figure 8: Ledger-specific Cost Rates for Quality Checks

Figure 9 shows a sample template to perform one quality check for each production order. The object in each case is the combination of cost center and activity type shown in the Object column. In this simple example the Plan quantity and Actual quantity we've entered a quantity of one manually, but you can also use functions to derive these quantities by clicking on the Plan Quantity or Actual Quantity column and choosing a function from the list. Here the charge will be applied in every period as the Plan activation and Actual activation columns are ACTIVE  but you can also use functions to determine the conditions under which a quality check should take place. 

Figure 9: Sample Template showing Activity Quantities

This template is linked to the cost estimate or the production order/process order via the combination of the costing sheet and overhead key as shown in Figure 10. 

Figure 10: Control Data for Production Order Showing the Costing Sheet and the Overhead Key

The link to the template is established in configuration (transaction KTPF) by linking the costing sheet and the overhead key with a template as shown in Figure 11.

Figure 11: Template Determination via Costing Sheet and Overhead Key

The cost center/activity type combinations entered in the template are automatically included in the standard cost estimate when you create a costing run using transaction CK40N or cost materials separately using transaction CK11N. Figure 12 shows a standard cost estimate (CK11N) with the template on the Valuation tab and the additional line for quality control in the itemization (Item No 22).

Figure 12: Sample Cost Estimate Showing Link to Template and Extra Line for Quality Check

For production orders and process orders you will need to run template allocation at period-close to collect the quantities relevant for allocation.  Template allocation is started using transaction CPTA for a single production order and CPTD for all orders in a plant. Figure 13 shows the result of running template allocation for a single production order with the template JS001 and cost rates in multiple ledgers.

Figure 13: Results of Template Allocation to Production Order

As the template allocation will result in additional costs on the production orders and process orders, you’ll need to use the Postprocess Event-Based Posting - Product Costing app (F3369) to make sure that these additional costs are reflected in the work in process and production variances posted for your open production orders. Figure 14 shows the journal entries from template allocation as Items to Post in the Postprocess Event-Based Postings - Product Costing app. You can trigger additional postings for work in process and/or production variances by selecting the Post button.

Figure 14: Journal Entries from Template Allocation

Closing Words

This approach radically simplifies organizations’ abilities to handle the requirements of different accounting principles in the area of overhead management and removes the need for significant manual work to reflect the different approaches on the true cost of goods sold.

Universal Parallel Accounting is still only delivered to pilot customers so it is important to compare the delivered scope with that required for your project, since functions that aren’t supported are not available in the SAP Easy Menu if the business function for universal parallel accounting is active.

If you are working with these types of allocation for the first time, please consider reading my detailed guide published by Rheinwerk Verlag.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 Product Release Highlights
entry.content:
Welcome to the SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 Product Release Highlights! In this blog, we will journey through the latest advancements of this pivotal update.

This release brings together strategy, innovation, and intelligence – uniting applications, data, and AI to help organizations transform how they operate and compete.

To get an overview of my personal highlights, you are welcome to watch my highlight video below.

 

 

Realizing our vision by bringing together apps, data, and AI

Whether it's refining finance with advanced AI agents, optimizing supply chain logistics, or advancing service management, each feature aims to enable agility and operational resilience. This release brings SAP's data strategy to life across applications, data integration and Business AI capabilities to empower businesses for the next leap. With AI at the top, SAP Business Data Cloud at the core, and deeply integrated applications as the foundation, organizations gain real-time insights, operational agility, and the ability to adapt and grow.

Our intelligent, modular, and configurable system is lifting ERP operations by placing people and roles at the forefront, surrounded by AI capabilities and intelligent agents. The integration with SAP Business Data Cloud enables organizations to unify and govern all SAP and third-party data, unlocking over 100 curated data products for richer insights and smarter decisions.

This update delivers innovations and enhancements across every line of business – from Finance and Sourcing and Procurement to Manufacturing, Sales, and Service. 

In the sections that follow, we’ll explore how these intelligent capabilities are enabling transformation across your ERP operations. 

 

Unleashing intelligence: SAP business AI and Joule AI agents at the forefront

Finance: Streamlining account receivables with Joule agent

In the area of Finance, SAP Cloud ERP Private introduces the beta version of the Joule agent for Accounts Receivables, contributing to financial management by streamlining overdue receivables analysis. Acting as a virtual assistant, the agent swiftly identifies overdue payments, provides detailed summaries, and recommends actionable next steps, transforming traditional analysis into strategic decision-making. It offers comprehensive insights into outstanding balances, open invoices, and disputes, empowering finance teams to improve cash flow management and reduce risk. This innovation allows accountants to focus on proactive financial strategies, enhancing operational efficiency. Stay tuned for the general availability release of this game-changing tool.

 For more details, visit the SAP Help Portal and check out our demo video below.

 

Supply Chain: Optimized warehouse operations with AI-assisted predictive labor demand planning

Speaking of the Supply Chain area, SAP Cloud ERP Private's AI-assisted predictive labor demand planning is enhancing warehouse operations by addressing labor shortages and rising delivery demands with greater confidence. Imagine your warehouse managers equipped to forecast short- and mid-term workload changes using both historical and real-time data. This innovative solution allows for precise planning of resources and workloads, improving efficiency in managing outbound delivery orders.

The tool provides seamless access to interactive charts and key performance indicators (KPIs), helping managers to monitor, analyze, and anticipate labor demand. Integrated with SAP Smart Business, it leverages AI to offer forecasts on planned and future workloads, enabling supervisors to better plan shifts, enhance transparency, and minimize potential delays. As a result, businesses boost customer satisfaction by ensuring timely delivery fulfillment.

 For more details on this solution, visit the SAP Help Portal and watch the demo video below.

 

Service Management: Equipment insights with Joule

In Service Management area, gaining a 360° view of equipment life cycles can transform your operational approach. With Joule integration, managers can assess equipment details, warranty information, and active service transactions, gaining insights into both customer and vendor warranties. AI-generated summaries capture the nuances of parts replaced and recurring issues, while offering recommendations for proactive management. This depth of information empowers service managers to make informed decisions, streamline operations, and enhance overall equipment effectiveness.

For more details, visit the SAP Help Portal and check out our demo video below.

 

 

Sourcing and Procurement: Purchase requisitions with AI-powered assistance

In the Sourcing and Procurement space, we are happy to introduce AI-assisted self-service requisitioning, simplifying the way purchase requisitions are created. Imagine casual users effortlessly engaging with Joule, an intuitive assistant that streamlines data entry and intelligently interprets misspelled information. This makes the requisition process accessible and user-friendly, eliminating the need for extensive navigation through multiple interfaces. Beyond just simplifying data input, Joule also leverages advanced language processing to understand and facilitate requests in diverse user languages, enhancing accuracy and efficiency. As a glimpse into the future, speech recognition promises to further reduce complexity, while simultaneously supporting purchasers by identifying sources of supply swiftly and minimizing reliance on free text items.

 Eager to learn more? Consult our SAP Help Portal.

 

Sales: Resolving sales order fulfillment challenges with AI assistance

In the sales area, SAP Cloud ERP Private introduces an AI-assisted sales order fulfillment process with Joule, designed to seamlessly address delivery, invoice, and supply challenges. Imagine having an assistant that not only identifies but explains the intricacies of fulfillment issues, spanning incomplete data, credit holds, billing discrepancies, and trade compliance blocks. As questions arise, Joule provides clear, AI-generated explanations of interconnected issues, displayed in an intuitive carousel format. Beyond resolving queries, it supports inquiries about supply chain and invoicing problems, as well as journal entry creation, making the entire process more transparent and manageable. This innovative tool streamlines sales operations, ensuring smoother transactions and greater clarity.

For further insights, explore the SAP Help Portal.

Now, let’s explore further innovations of the current release across various lines of business.

 

Turning data into value: A unified data foundation with SAP Business Data Cloud

In today’s enterprise landscape, data is the engine of transformation. With SAP Business Data Cloud, organizations can unify and govern their most valuable data – across SAP and third-party sources – enabling real-time insights and smarter decisions at every level. 

 

A unified data foundation for every business need

SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 delivers seamless integration with SAP Business Data Cloud, providing a governed, harmonized data layer that supports analytics, planning, and AI-driven innovation. This foundation breaks down silos and ensures that leaders have access to trusted, business-ready data. 

For more information, consult our page on integration with SAP Business Data Cloud.

Industry-ready data products

The release introduces a broad set of data products tailored for diverse business scenarios:

  • Convergent invoicing: Data products for billing requests, plans, and documents enable near-real-time analytics and interactive dashboards.
  • Contract accounting: Rich data products for contract accounts, provider contracts, and accounting documents support deeper financial analysis.
  • Subscription management: Data products for subscription orders, contracts, and agreements provide actionable insights for recurring revenue models.
  • Manufacturing: Unified manufacturing data – such as production orders, confirmations, and work centers – empowers leaders to optimize operations. Eager to learn more on manufacturing data products? Consult our SAP Help portal.
  • Product lifecycle management: Enhanced data products for bills of material, engineering change masters, and change records drive better product and change management. For more information, click here.

For the information on all released data products, please refer to Business Accelerator Hub. 

 

From data to action: Working capital dashboard

A standout example is the working capital dashboard for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud. By leveraging harmonized data from finance, procurement, and supply chain, this dashboard gives finance leaders real-time visibility into cash flow, receivables, and payables – enabling proactive, data-driven decisions to optimize working capital.

 

SAP Business Data Cloud is not just a technology layer – it’s the strategic enabler that turns data into value, powering the next wave of business transformation.

 

Strengthening the core: Innovations in business applications

 

Finance

Taulia: Contributing to cash flow and supply chain resilience 

Additionally, SAP Cloud ERP Private's integration with SAP Taulia benefits cash flow optimization and supply chain resilience. By leveraging real-time data insights, businesses enhance cash management and strengthen supplier relationships, allowing precise management of early payments and discounts. This boosts liquidity, enabling reinvestment in growth while maintaining supply chain stability. The integration streamlines financial processes, fostering transparency and a robust dialogue between buyers and suppliers. Empowered to manage cash flow proactively and reduce risks, organizations achieve greater agility and resilience.

 For more insights, explore SAP Help Portal.

 

Supply Chain

Streamlining order management with aATP Innovation

The current release introduces important enhancements to the Advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP) capabilities, designed to make order management more intelligent and efficient. These capabilities aim to instill confidence in order confirmations while simultaneously reducing inventory carrying costs, delivering tangible business benefits from the outset.

Picture a business environment where timely delivery is key to customer satisfaction and brand reputation. The new features enable companies to confirm orders with confidence, capitalizing on advanced backorder processing. This flexibility allows users to bypass traditional constraints such as Product Availability Check (PAC), Product Allocation (PAL), and Supply Protection (SUP). As a result, businesses can reliably and accurately fulfill customer needs, ensuring the loyalty that comes from dependable service.

The innovation further streamlines logistics by automating transport order creation, facilitating the smooth movement of stock from substitute locations to the requested site. This automation reduces the need for manual intervention, minimizing errors, and promoting a seamless logistics process. Imagine the operational relief this brings, letting companies dedicate resources to strategic tasks rather than repetitive logistics management.

By introducing efficient availability checks for configured and long products, businesses achieve effective inventory management. This ensures readiness aligns perfectly with demand, paving the way for higher fulfillment rates and precise delivery dates, enhancing overall customer satisfaction.

Additionally, we are happy to introduce the Alternative-Based Confirmation with Stock Transport Document Creation, a feature designed to streamline and improve logistical processes. This innovation allows businesses to consolidate shipments by ensuring that sales order items ship from the originally requested location rather than alternative stock-holding sites. This is particularly beneficial in maintaining a consistent supply chain, reducing the chances of logistical errors.

In the context of international shipping, this feature proves invaluable. It ensures goods are consolidated at locations best suited for tariff and tax declarations, thereby facilitating smoother, compliant export processes. Companies can navigate complex export requirements more confidently, knowing that their logistical operations support rather than hinder compliance.

 

Activation of this feature is notably flexible, accommodating various sales order characteristics. It automates stock reservations and generates necessary transportation documents as the orders are saved, reducing the manual workload associated with these tasks. This automation enhances the accuracy of transportation planning and scheduling, ensuring that these tasks align perfectly with business needs.

Eager to learn more? Consult this dedicated page  on SAP Help portal.

 

Service Management

Enhancing internal logistics: Optimized management of in-house service objects

Additionally, we are introducing a noteworthy advancement with the intracompany logistics feature for in-house service objects. This functionality empowers businesses to efficiently manage service objects within the same company code, enhancing logistical operations and resource utilization. It allows for the seamless transfer of an in-house service object between plants or storage locations, utilizing existing customer stock effectively. This capability not only optimizes space and resources but also streamlines internal logistics processes, ensuring service objects are handled with increased precision.

Businesses can now define and display the plant and storage locations of service objects, providing clearer visibility and control over inventory management. Furthermore, receiving service objects is made more efficient through the introduction of options to receive them directly via inbound delivery. This directly addresses the need for improved logistical coordination within companies, facilitating a more synchronized workflow when handling service objects.

Choosing between customer stock B and returns order stock E offers flexibility in how service objects are managed based on specific business requirements. The graphical process flow provides access to logistics-related documents, helping users quickly ascertain the status and movement of service objects. Additionally, receiving service objects at specified plant or storage locations, and reviewing their current location on the UI, enhances day-to-day operational efficiency and accuracy.

For more details, explore the SAP Help portal.

 

Driving agility: Real-time service management with enhanced service transactions

In today's dynamic business environment, flexibility is paramount for companies looking to stay competitive. In the current release, we introduce one more subtle yet powerful enhancement to service management area: the integration of plant and storage location fields within service transaction items. This advancement isn’t just a technical upgrade; it's a strategic lever for businesses aiming to enhance their operational agility.

Imagine a scenario where your company needs to rapidly adjust service delivery due to sudden market changes or resource constraints. With these new capabilities, changing the plant and storage location directly in service transactions becomes seamless, enabling you to adapt your logistics in real-time. This flexibility means that resources can be reallocated swiftly, improving response times and aligning services more closely with customer expectations.

Such adaptability transforms how businesses manage their logistics, turning service operations into a strategic advantage rather than a mere necessity. The ability to dynamically adjust service parameters according to evolving business needs not only streamlines processes but also ensures that service delivery remains efficient and customer-centric.

To dive into further details, don’t hesitate to explore the SAP Help portal page.

 

Asset Management

Streamlined maintenance strategies: Enhancing asset health

In the realm of asset management, SAP Cloud ERP Private introduces the beta version of enhancements with Maintenance Planner and Maintenance Order Management, integrating seamlessly with Joule to improve how maintenance is orchestrated. Consider a planner working hand-in-hand with an intelligent agent, dynamically analyzing real-time data to fine-tune maintenance schedules and improve asset health. Joule leverages technical object details to create maintenance planning buckets, offering planners a clear view of upcoming events and enabling seamless assignment of orders and notifications. Additionally, by checking available slots and reserving production capacities for future operations, downtime is minimized, fostering a more proactive maintenance approach. This integrated system not only optimizes workflows but empowers teams to make informed decisions, ensuring that assets remain in prime condition.

For more details, explore the SAP Help Portal.

 

Optimizing asset management: Tailored efficiency in maintenance operations

In the asset management landscape, SAP Cloud ERP Private enhances the “Manage Maintenance Orders” app to empower businesses with greater efficiency and customization. Imagine a streamlined operation where you effortlessly customize fields and processes to fit your unique needs. This app now allows batch editing of maintenance orders and the inclusion of multiple task lists, simplifying complex workflows and maximizing resource utilization. Picture the ease of linking business partners directly to orders, ensuring transparency and fostering stronger collaborations. This enhanced visibility ensures smoother communication and stronger partnerships, ultimately leading to improved service delivery and outcomes.

Interested to learn more? Click here!

 

 

Sourcing and Procurement

Precision in procurement: Elevating efficiency with synchronized service timelines

In the context of SAP procurement, timing is everything. SAP Cloud ERP Private’s latest enhancement allows for seamless transfer of lean service start and end dates to connected backend systems, shifting the focus from traditional delivery dates to precise service durations.

Visualize a scenario where procurement teams can boost efficiency significantly by having accurate service timelines at their disposal. This synchronization ensures that everyone, from procurement officers to backend users, operates with the same timeline data, reducing discrepancies and enhancing planning accuracy. With this new capability, businesses gain a strategic advantage, as coordinated planning between departments becomes the norm rather than the exception.

Think of the impact on your business: with synchronized service data, your teams can efficiently coordinate with service providers, ensuring that every commitment is met with precision. This results in improved operational harmony and more reliable partnerships. This innovative feature boosts your procurement efficiency, aligning strategic objectives with everyday operations. For more details on how this can transform your processes, explore the linked page.  

 

Sales

Enhancing sales efficiency with one-step-payment

In the ever-evolving landscape of digital commerce, SAP Cloud ERP Private now empowers businesses to streamline their sales processes through pre-order payments. This innovation allows customers to make payments even before a sales order is created, seamlessly integrating payment details into the sales order via an API. By carrying over liability and payment details to the finance application, businesses can efficiently match liabilities against payments, simplifying settlements and reducing days sales outstanding (DSO). This enhancement not only enhances liquidity and reduces financing costs but also appeals to customers who prefer paying upfront, offering a more flexible purchasing experience. Furthermore, it facilitates faster incoming digital payments, reassuring customers with the stability and responsiveness of a modern finance system.

Want to learn more about Payment Processing? Check out our SAP Help Portal.

 

Manufacturing

Seamless production alignment with advanced MRP solutions

In a quest to enhance operational efficiency, we are introducing innovative features for Material Requirements Planning (MRP) in Manufacturing area. The Accept MRP Run Result functionality allows production planners to flag specific segments as processed, streamlining decision-making by focusing on issues that truly need attention. This improvement, coupled with the ability to use a new filter field, empowers end users to efficiently analyze material coverage for thousands of materials daily, marking a significant enhancement in workflow efficiency. Additionally, the Manage Material Coverage app now offers rescheduling proposals, enabling planners to realign MRP elements by rescheduling or canceling as necessary. These real-time adjustments ensure that manufacturing requirements are always met as planned, minimizing disruptions and maintaining smooth production flows. With the option to invoke or revoke MRP results, businesses gain flexibility in their planning processes, adapting swiftly to changing demands. Ultimately, this upgrade facilitates a more agile and responsive manufacturing environment, ensuring that production aligns seamlessly with demand predictions.

 

For more details, explore the our dedicated pages on accept planning result of MRP run and rescheduling proposals for MRP elements.    

 

Cross Topics

Enhancing business engagement through integrated communications

With the current release, SAP Cloud ERP Private improves organizations’ ability to craft and deliver personalized, traceable communications seamlessly within their existing workflows. This innovation ensures consistent and timely interactions with business contacts by setting up automated, multi-step communication flows that operate both regularly and in response to specific events. By allowing ad-hoc communications directly from the current process step, businesses maintain critical context without ever leaving the system. This not only enhances productivity and transparency but also significantly boosts customer satisfaction by providing tailored communication that meets the unique needs of each business partner. With these capabilities, organizations can foster stronger relationships industry-wide, ensuring every message is delivered effectively and efficiently.

The automation and ease of use offered by Joule Copilot significantly elevate the handling of business partner data, allowing businesses to maintain accurate and timely records with minimal effort. entry.title: SAP S/4HANA 2025: What's in it for the Utilities Industry?
entry.content:
The newest version of SAP S/4HANA has just been released to customers. Here is an overview about its main innovations that are dedicated to the utilities industry:

  • Market process management and prepayment for utilities moved into SAP S/4HANA Utilities: 
    Two former add-ons are now technically part of SAP S/4HANA - which means you do not need to install an add-on any more on top of S/4HANA to take advantage of their rich functionality:
    • Market process management for Utilities , enables you to efficiently model, execute, and monitor your market processes,including message handling for communication with market partners, in liberalized energy markets
    • Prepayment for utilities, offers your customers the option to prepay their energy consumption,

  • Conversational search on application help (SAP S/4HANA Utilities) through the Joule copilot allows you to express questions to SAP S/4HANA Utilities in natural language and have them instantly answered based on the available SAP Help Portal documentation.

  • Using SAP Datasphere in the utilities industry – utilities sales contracts
    You can now extract utilities sales contract data from S/4HANA Utilities to SAP Datasphere for comprehensive analytics and reporting purposes, also leveraging SAP Analytics Cloud. This capability enables utilities companies to leverage their sales contract data for advanced business intelligence and decision-making.
    For a complete overview of available CDS views that enable extraction of utilities business objects to SAP Datasphere, see CDS Views for Utilities Business Objects and Application Areas.

  • Innovation Sales integration interface: discounting, process resilience, and scheduling offers automatic restart capabilities to recover temporary disruptions in the sales process for energy products.

  • Utilities product integration layer (UPIL) support for price guarantees is now available based on an enhanced appointment management for utilities sales contracts, enabling you to define and maintain period control data more effectively.

  • Customization for date fields in utilities contracts allows you to efficiently manage contract durations, renewal dates, and other scheduling data. 


  • Following the Customer Fields and Logic concept of SAP NetWeaver, it is now easier to add your own additional attributes to the point-of-delivery master data and to clarification cases, see Enabling custom fields and logic for point-of-delivery and BPEM case data. Key-user extensibility is one element of SAP's Clean Core strategy, see SAP note 3406389 for a comprehensive overview on Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Utilities.

  • Business events for technical objects for utilities  enables integration of SAP S/4HANA Utilities with external applications. SAP S/4HANA 2025 provide such events for the entities connection object, device location, premise, installation and point of delivery, Note that business events are already available for utilities sales contracts.

  • Budget billing plans in the Business Partner Financial Overview app
    The SAP Fiori app Business Partner Financial Overview now includes a new facet showing further utilities-industry specific data

entry.title: From Customer Org. Chart to SAP Org. Structure
entry.content:
Hello SAP Gurus,
While diving deep into the world of SAP ERP for over 10 years, I wanted to share some of my findings and experience on a topic that can be a challenge for many of us: How to Design the Customer’s Organization Hierarchy into SAP Enterprise Structure.

It's great to deploy what the SAP best practice says, but from the customer perspective it’s very sensitive step as it’s reflecting the overall business decisions. I recognized this during my career in implementing SAP projects, and I hope my findings can help you out there for whom might be starting on a similar journey.

Bridging the Gap Between Customer's Org. Chart and SAP Enterprise Structure

We all have our company's organizational chart hanging somewhere in the office or in a PowerPoint file. It shows the customer's department hierarchy, who reports to whom, and how teams are structured.

But how do we take that familiar hierarchy and map it to SAP's world of Company Codes, Plants, and Purchasing Organizations? It's not always a one-to-one match, and that's where the complexity (and honestly, the fun!) begins.

I found an example of this in old SAP Community question from 2008. A community user laid out a detailed case study of a company with 4 factories, 3 regional distribution centers, 15 sales offices, in addition of an R&D team and project management team. It was a fantastic real world scenario that highlighted the tough question we often face.

"since material from Plant and RDC is being transferred to Branches and from there it is distributed to customers therefore the valuation of FG at BRANCH and RDC should be different as transportation cost, packing, unpacking etc cost should get added at Branch level. Therefore in case I make branch as Storage location, I will miss the valuation part while if I make them as Plant then there will be lot of documents get generated for each movement."

This is exactly the kind of practical dilemma that gets to the heart of enterprise structure design. It's a constant balancing act between financial accuracy and operational efficiency.

Understanding The SAP Organizational Units

Before we define and assign the SAP enterprise structure, we need to know exactly what of each SAP org. unit represents. It’s helpful to think of them in a hierarchical way, starting from the top.

  1. Client: the highest level in the SAP system hierarchy. Specifications that you make, or data that you enter at this level are valid for all company codes and for all other organizational structures. You therefore only need to make these specifications, or enter this data once. This ensures that the data is consistent.
  2. Company Codes: is the central organizational unit of external accounting within the SAP System. You must define at least one company code before implementing the Financial Accounting component. The business transactions relevant for Financial Accounting are entered, saved, and evaluated at company code level.
  3. Plant: organizational unit serving to subdivide an enterprise according to production, procurement, maintenance, and materials planning aspects. It is a place where either materials are produced or goods and services provided.
  4. Purchasing Organizations and Purchasing Groups: An organizational unit subdividing an enterprise according to the requirements of Purchasing. It procures materials and services, negotiates conditions of purchase with vendors, and is responsible for such transactions. A purchasing group is a key for a buyer or group of buyers in SAP ERP. It is responsible for the procurement of a material or class of materials, and is the principal channel for a company's dealings with its suppliers.

Organizational Unit

Key Characteristics

Typical Use Cases

Client

Highest level, represents entire corporate group

One per SAP system

Company Code

Legal entity with independent financial statements

Subsidiaries, country operations

Plant

Operational unit where business activities occur

Factories, warehouses, sales offices

Storage Location

Physical storage area within a Plant

Warehouse sections, storage areas

Purchasing Org

Defines procurement scope and authority

Centralized or decentralized procurement

Purchasing Group

Actual procurement team or buyer

Commodity teams, regional buyers

A Visual Approach to Mapping

I'm a visual learner, so diagrams really help me solidify these concepts. I've created a couple of diagrams to illustrate how a typical departmental structure might map to SAP organizational units, and how those units relate to each other.
Here's a conceptual mapping from real-world departments to SAP units:

And here's a more detailed example of what a complete SAP organizational hierarchy might looks like, incorporating multiple company codes, plants, and purchasing organizations:

My Key Takeaways and Learned Lessons

After implementing a lot of SAP projects, here are some advices I have heard from my leaders:

Start with the "Why," Not the "What." Don't just create organizational units because they exist in your company. Think about your business processes and reporting requirements first. What do the customer need to see in his financial reports? How he manage his inventory? How do he want to analyze his procurement activities and expenses? The answers to these questions should guide you WHAT is the correct design decisions.

  1. The Plant is probably the most versatile org. unit in SAP. I've seen Plants used to represent everything from manufacturing facilities to service centers. Don't be afraid to think creatively about how to use Plants to model your business operations. Just remember that each Plant needs to be assigned to a Company Code, so plan accordingly. And remember that SAP defines the plant as a logistics organizational element that is used by all the logistics modules. The plant is assigned to a company code that may have many plants assigned to it. A plant is typically configured in conjunction with the company code and valuation area due to tax rules and regulations.
    Depending on the role the plant has in the organization, a plant can be defined for the following purposes:
    • In Sales and Distribution (SD), a location from which finished goods and materials are stored and distributed.
    • A location from which services are rendered.
    • Materials Management (MM), a location where material flow is managed and stock requirements are managed from both the inbound and outbound perspectives.
    • A location where material stock is consumed, planned, and purchased.
    • A manufacturing facility where materials are produced, as in Production Planning (PP).
  2. Purchasing org. structure has a huge impact on your procurement processes, approval workflows, and reporting. I learned that the hard way when we had to redesign our purchasing structure because we hadn't thought through the implications properly. Take time to understand whether a centralized or decentralized org. unit makes the most sense for your company.
  3. Plan for Growth and Change, Your first design probably won't be perfect, and your business will expand over time. Build flexibility into your design where possible, and don't be afraid to iterate, I've seen too many implementations get stuck because they tried to create the "perfect" structure from day one instead of starting with something good and improving it over time.
  4. Document Your Decisions, This might seem obvious, but document not just what you designed, but why you designed it. think in future questions, when someone ask why the regional sales offices are defined as plants instead of storage locations, you'll be glad that you wrote your reasoning.

Important Considerations

in past implementations i've encountered some comments from the customer that might help you think through your own design:

  1. Multi-Country Operations: If the customer operates in multiple countries, you'll likely need separate company codes for each country due to legal and tax requirements, but you might be able to share plants across company codes for operational efficiency.
  2. Shared Transactions: If the customer has shared service centers (like a centralized IT department or shared warehouse), think carefully about how to define and assign these on SAP, sometimes they're best represented as separate org. units, sometimes as cost centers within existing org. units.
  3. Acquisitions and Divestitures: If the company invest in other legal entities by frequently acquires or divests business units, design the SAP structure to make these transitions easier, this might mean keeping acquired companies as separate company codes initially, even if the customer plan to integrate them later.

Summery

SAP Enterprise Structure design is a piece of art, a part of business administration science, and a part of overall company growth.
There's no one "correct" way to do it, but there are definitely wrong ways, the key here is to understand customer business requirements, think through the implications of your design, and be prepared to adapt as you may learn later.

I hope my thoughts and findings has been helpful for you, and I'm always learning new things about SAP organizational structures, so I'd love to hear your thoughts and experiences.

  • What challenges have you faced when mapping customer's organization in SAP?
  • What advice would you give to SAP community members or for a someone has just starting out?
  • Have you encountered any particularly creative or unusual organizational structure designs?

entry.title: Goods Receipt Reversal for External Procurement in EWM - SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to explain how to cancel the Goods Receipt after Final Putaway for External Procurement in Extended Warehouse Management, in addition to demonstrating the process steps for testing, we will also discuss about potential errors and current limitations.

This new Monitor Mehtod is available in both EWM deployments: Embedded and Decentralized.

Background Information:

With the new Method 'Reverse after Putaway' in Warehouse Management Monitor (i.e. As of SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0), it is now finally possible to reverse a goods receipt for an inbound delivery/item in external procurement scenario (e.g. Purchase Order) in EWM, even if the Putaway Warehouse Task is already confirmed.

This gives the warehouse team more flexibility to trigger GR reversal at anytime when the error is observed maybe during picking, as long as the reference purchase documents are still exist in system (i.e. not Archived).

The new Monitor Method (Reverse after Putaway) can be found in the following nodes in SAP Warehouse Management Monitor report (/SCWM/MON):
- Stock and Bin -> Physical Stock 
- Stock and Bin -> Storage Bin -> Physical Stock


Figure 01 - Simple Inbound Process Flow

Prerequisites:

  • Completion Status (DCO) for delivery item to be cancelled must be equal to 9-Completed
  • Purchase document is not archived
  • Quality inspection document is completed (if exists)
  • Authorization object /SCWM/SLFU with the value RS for Reverse Stock from External Procurement is assigned to your user.

Configuration Steps:

This configuration step is only required in Decentralized EWM deplopyment.

- Allow Reversal after Putaway for Completed LE Delivery
Navigate to SPRO -> Extended Warehouse Management-> Interfaces->ERP Integration->ERP Integration for Decentralized EWM-> Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control


Figure 02 - Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control

Testing Steps:

NOTE: The following testing scenario has been executed on SAP S/4HANA OP2025 FPS00 with Embedded EWM.

Scenario: GR Reversal for Inbound Delivery with reference to a Purchase Order:
In this scenario we will post goods receipt for an inbound delivery created with reference to a purchase order, then we will trigger the goods receipt reversal for the received delivery item via the new Monitor Method (Reverse after Putaway) in Warehouse Monitor report.

1- Create Purchase Order (Tx. ME21N / App. Create Purchase Order - Advanced)


Figure 03 - Create Purchase Order

2- Create Inbound Delivery in Logistics Execution (Tx. VL31N / App. Create Inbound Delivery)


Figure 04 - Create Inbound Delivery in LE

3- Post Goods Receipt in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Maintain Inbound Deliveries)


Figure 05 - Post GR in EWM


4- Create Putaway Warehouse Tasks  (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Create Warehouse Tasks - Inbound Delivery)


Figure 06 - Create Putaway WTs

Hint: don't forget to take a note of the destination storage bin number, to use it later on during the reversal step.

5- Confirm Putaway Warehouse Tasks (Tx. /SCWM/MON / App. Warehouse Monitor)


Figure 07 - Confirm Putaway WTs

6- Reverse Goods Receipt in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/MON / App. Warehouse Monitor)
 - Navigate to Warehouse Management Monitor report -> Stock and Bin -> Physical Stock.
- Select the stock line and click on More Methods -> Reverse after Putaway.


Figure 08/A - Select Reverse after Putaway method

 - Ensure to enter the exact quantity to be reversed. 
- You need to enter Inbound Delivery and Item numbers as well (if not proposed by system, in case of multiple reference documents exist).
- Then click Post GR Reversal button.


Figure 08/B - Post GR Reverseal in EWM

Hint: Material Document year/number/item could be entered as well if desired.

- If goods receipt reversal is successful, then a Warehouse Task of category 6-Goods Issue Posting will be created.


Figure 08/C - WT for GI is created

7- Check Inbound Delivery in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Maintain Inbound Deliveries) - Optional


Figure 09 - Check Inbound Delivery in EWM

In EWM inbound delivery, Goods Receipt and Putaway statutes will remain Completed (no changes).

8- Check Inbound Delivery in Logistics Execution  (Tx. VL33N / App. Display Inbound Delivery) - Optional


Figure 10/A - Check Inbound Delivery GM Status in LE

In LE inbound delivery, the Goods Receipt status will remain Completed (no changes).


Figure 10/B - Check Inbound Delivery Document Flow in LE

But in the document flow, a goods reversal material document (w/ movement type 102) will be created and added.

9- Check Purchase Order History in ERP (Tx. ME23N  / App. Display Purchase Order)


Figure 11 - Check PO History in ERP

NOTE: In case the missing item has been delivered by supplier later on after the goods receipt reversal for the same item was executed, a new inbound delivery should be created in this case as re-posting goods receipt for same inbound delivery item which was reversed is not possible.

 

Common Errors during Goods Receipt Reversal:

- M7328 - Deficit of Delivered quantity:
In case you enter higher quantity than original delivery item quantity.

- /SCWM/GM401 - Reversal for stock assigned to reference documents is not allowed:
In case you select a stock line with a delivery reference (i.e. DCO <> 9) or you select a stock item with open quality inspection document.

- /SCWM/GM402 - Stock Information in delivery/item - doesn't match selected stock:
In case you select a different stock line that doesn't match the inserted delivery information.

 

Out of Scope:

  • Posting goods receipt for same inbound delivery item which was revesred.
  • Serial number managed materials. (only via API is possible)
  • Catch weight managed materials.
  • Purchase documents are archived.
  • STO, Merchandise Cross docking, and TCD.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:

It's now possible to reverse goods receipt after final putaway in EWM for external procurment scenario, using the new Monitor Method - Reversal after Putaway in Warehouse Management Report, the warehouse user is now able to trigger goods receipt reversal in EWM and ERP respectively without too much complexity or additional technical knowledge. 

You can also use the API interface /SCWM/IF_API_RVS_STOCK_PTWY in a custom development to perform the reversal.

For more information about reversal after putaway, please check Reversal of Goods Receipt from External Procurement | SAP Help Portal.
